newsitem.title: USA: US debt futures end off in quiet pre-weekend trade.
newsitem.headline: US debt futures end off in quiet pre-weekend trade.

text.p: U.S. debt futures ended lower in very quiet pre-weekend trade.
Traders said the market ground to a virtual stop by midday and key contracts remained locked in tight ranges in the afternoon.
With this week's abundance of economic stimuli behind them, players took to the sidelines ahead of an equally jam-packed line-up next week.
The market "looks swell but it kind of lost its momentum right now and with all this news out next week people are probably going to sit back and prepare," a trader said.

Traders were especially keen for the second-quarter employment cost index, due Tuesday. The previous report showed an 0.6-percent gain. Also on tap are a quarterly refunding announcement, second-quarter gross domestic product, and July payrolls data.

"It should be an active week," a Eurodollar trader said. He noted minor pre-weekend positioning early, and said many local traders left the pits by midday, leaving trade in the short end at a standstill late Friday.
Debt futures dipped to lows early on June durable goods orders, then turned up after existing home sales.
June durable goods rose 2.3 percent, compared with a forecast for a 1.4 percent gain and an upwardly revised drop of 0.4 percent in May.
June existing home sales fell 2.6 percent to a 4.14 million annual rate, compared with a forecast for a 4.19 million rate.
Overall, traders said the market still holds a firm tone, and said the week's action remained bullish.
"There are not really a lot of bad things you can say about the market," a trader said.
September Treasury bond futures achieved a new high for the year at 115-23/32 during the week and closed nearly a point above last week's 114-06/32 close.

At the close, September T-bonds were off 9/32 at 115-01/32, 10-year notes were down 5/32 at 110-00, muni-bonds fell 10/32 to 120-22/32, December Eurodollars gave up 0.015 to 94.125, and December T-bills ended flat at 94.815. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750)) E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com
